sorting2014

Class QuickSort

  • java.lang.Object
    • sorting2014.QuickSort
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Sorter

    public class QuickSort
extends java.lang.Object
implements Sorter
    QuickSort is a divide-and-conquer based sorting algorithm. The algorithm takes a set of unsorted items, 'partitions' them by selecting a 'pivot' (an element from the list), and then partitioning the remaining elements to different sides of the list, based on whether they are greater than or less than the pivot.

    Those less than and greater than sections are then themselves put through the same QuickSort partitioning process.

    This is repeated until there are partitions the size of a single element. When this is the result, the list is sorted, as each element has been put either to the greater or less than side of pivots throughout the process, gradually putting each element into the correct index.

    quickSort based on pseudo-code from: http://bit.ly/1kCvXur partitioning based on pseudo-code from Richard Shipman's (rcs@aber.ac.uk) slides from lectures at Aberystwyth University.

    Author:
    - James Euesden

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      private int partition(java.lang.Comparable[] items, int first, int last)
      Partitioning a section is taking the left-most and right-most indexes of the section, the first and last indexes of the section, respectively, and using the firstIndex's element as a pivot, put those items that are less than it to the left side of the section, and those that are greater than it to the right side of the section.
      private void quickSort(java.lang.Comparable[] items, int left, int right)
      A recursive function that first checks that there is more than one element in the partition (through checking that the left of the partition is not the same as or greater than the right).
      void sort(java.lang.Comparable[] items, int cutoff)
      Calls to quickSort to begin the sorting algorithm.

      • sort

        public void sort(java.lang.Comparable[] items,
        int cutoff)
        Calls to quickSort to begin the sorting algorithm.
        Specified by:
        sort in interface Sorter
        Parameters:
        items - - The unsorted list.
        cutoff - - When the sort should stop.

      • quickSort

        private void quickSort(java.lang.Comparable[] items,
             int left,
             int right)
        A recursive function that first checks that there is more than one element in the partition (through checking that the left of the partition is not the same as or greater than the right). The method then partitions the left and the right side of the list, and returns the 'pivot', separating the less than and greater than sides of the list.

        This pivot is then used with the right most and left most indexes in the current partition to conduct another quickSort on those individual partitions, gradually sorting the list through dividing and conquering.

        Parameters:
        items - - The unsorted array.
        left - - The left most index of the section.
        right - - The right most index of the section.

      • partition

        private int partition(java.lang.Comparable[] items,
            int first,
            int last)
        Partitioning a section is taking the left-most and right-most indexes of the section, the first and last indexes of the section, respectively, and using the firstIndex's element as a pivot, put those items that are less than it to the left side of the section, and those that are greater than it to the right side of the section.
        Parameters:
        items - - The unsorted array.
        first - - The first index of the current section to be sorted.
        last - - The last index of the current section to be sorted.
        Returns:
        - The current pivot position, where the partition between lists is.
